newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Ivorians form new farm union as reforms loom.
newsitem.headline: Ivorians form new farm union as reforms loom.

text.p: Ivorian farmers set up a new union at the weekend to cope with plans to reduce the state's role in commodities marketing, the government daily newspaper Fraternite-Matin said on Tuesday.

The Union des Agriculteurs de Cote d'Ivoire, formed at the weekend, would help its 700 members to "organise marketing of produce, basic healthcare, savings and credit, and provide information on farmers' rights", it said, quoting UNIACI's president, Amani Koffi.

Ivory Coast last week concluded talks on liberalising the external marketing of coffee and cocoa sectors by 1998/99 (Oct-Sept) and 1999/2000 respectively which will cut the role of the state Caistab marketing board.
Internal marketing was liberalised in 1995/96 but donors have pushed for further reforms to the former monopoly as a condition for agriculture loans.
Union members also discussed rubber, tropical fruit, tobacco, sugar, aquaculture and livestock sectors.
One of the country's largest farm unions, SYNAGCI, recently expressed support for sweeping liberalisation urged by the World Bank. Others, including UNIACI, are more reserved.

Agriculture minister Lambert Kouassi Konan has said farmers' professional bodies and cooperatives would be given funding to help them set up their own cocoa and coffee marketing structures and compete with existing buyers and exporters.
